Award.AwardTitle: Ocean Acidification: Oxygen-limited CO2 Tolerance in Squids (Ommastrephidaw and Loliginidae)
Award.AbstractNarration: The present proposal is aimed at predicting the consequences of ocean acidification on ecosystem health and function. Specifically, it addresses the extent to which the combined effects of ocean acidification, global warming and expanding hypoxia may affect energetics of squids. Squids provide a critical link in oceanic food chains, feeding on the massive zooplankton populations and serving as prey to fish and mammalian predators. Their growth rates and maximum sizes are plastic, reflecting the changing ecosystem. As such, they respond quickly to environmental conditions and serve as real time indicators of ecosystem health. Oceanic squids are the only non-calcifying organisms whose sensitivity to ocean acidification was specifically predicted based on highly pH-sensitive oxygen binding by hemocyanin, the blood pigment of squids. Only a single study has tested this prediction, finding that elevated CO2 constrains metabolism and activity levels in the jumbo squid, Dosidicus gigas. The proposed analysis will integrate across levels of performance, from cell, to systemic, to whole-animal function, comparing squid species with variable blood-oxygen binding properties and CO2 exposure histories. It will addresses the combined effects of declining environmental oxygen, increasing oxygen demand due to warming, and reduced oxygen transport due to high CO2 on the function of these "high-performance" invertebrates. These squids are ecologically and commercially important and are believed to be the most CO2-sensitive non-calcifying taxa. The proposed research effort will be complemented by an extensive education and outreach effort in collaboration with the Ocean Exploration Trust and aboard the E/V Nautilus in the Caribbean in summer 2013 and 2014. E/V Nautilus operates under a new paradigm of "telepresence-enabled" expeditions. Satellite and high-bandwidth Internet2 technology transmits data, including remotely operated vehicle (ROV) video feeds, to shore in real time, supporting the participation of science teams around the world and reaching a growing public and student population. Moreover, the Nautilus program is teamed up with the JASON Project that brings marine science to K-12 classrooms via curriculum development. The investigators on this project will contribute time and expertise in ocean acidification to the development of a new curriculum on Climate and Oceanography and develop a webcast for the JASON Live interactive series that will be broadcast from sea with Nautilus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean acidification due to diffusion of anthropogenic atmospheric PCO2 into the oceans causes a reduction in pH and an increase in PCO2 of the surface ocean.  Seawater PCO2 will cross biological membranes (e.g. gills) until a new gradient is established that permits excretion of metabolically produced CO2.  This elevation in blood and tissue PCO2 may effect behavior, calcification, metabolism and oxygen transport among others.  Cephalopods, due to their highly pH-sensitive oxygen binding protein, Hemocyanin, are hypothesized to be especially sensitive to elevated environmental PCO2.  However, model calculations suggest that, because the blood is well buffered and acid-base regulation fairly robust in squids, the effect of ocean acidification is expected to be minimal or non-existent.  Here we conducted experiments to test these conflicting expectations.  The critical oxygen partial pressure (Pcrit) is the oxygen level where oxygen demand exactly matches oxygen supply, and is often used as an indication of a species tolerance to low oxygen.  Thus any further reduction in oxygen supply due to the effect of elevated PCO2 on blood-oxygen transport should be apparent as an increase in the Pcrit.  We measured the Pcrits of two commercially and ecologically important squid species, both of which are known to have pH-sensitive oxygen transport proteins.  Neither Dosidicus gigas, nor Doryteuthis pealei, showed any increase in Pcrit (no reduction in tolerance to low oxygen) under PCO2 levels expected by the end of the century.  This was true across the range of temperatures tested.  The effect of temperature on Pcrit suggests, however, that ocean warming and deoxygenation will influence the vertical and latitudinal distributions of both species.

This work was documented by Open Boat Films and has been illustrated in several short videos that are being used in teaching, community education and outreach, and science presentation.  We further took advantage of opportunities to educate the public about ocean acidification by visiting a natural CO2 vent (undersea volcano) near Grenada.  The effects of this high CO2 environment on the surrounding seawater chemistry and biology were profound and were broadcast live to a wide audience via Nautiluslive.com.
